HL7 Standard.summary: This Implementation Guide focuses on building a FHIR-based messaging framework for unsolicited notifications. It heavily relies on FHIR resources and operations, particularly the Bundle and MessageHeader resources, and the $process-message operation. While it acknowledges other HL7 standards, it does not directly utilize or integrate them into its core functionality.

Geographic Scope.summary: The Da Vinci Unsolicited Notifications Implementation Guide is built upon FHIR R4 and US Core R4, and references the Da Vinci Health Record Exchange (HRex) IG. It is explicitly stated as being relevant to the US healthcare system and aligns with the Da Vinci project's goals of supporting value-based care. Therefore, it is a national guide for the United States.

Domain Focus.summary: The Da Vinci Unsolicited Notifications IG primarily focuses on enabling real-time communication of patient care events, particularly admissions, transfers, and discharges, between providers and payers. It leverages FHIR messaging to facilitate care coordination and management. While it touches upon administrative aspects and includes clinical data, its core purpose revolves around workflow and the timely exchange of event notifications.

Implementers.summary: The Da Vinci Unsolicited Notifications IG primarily focuses on real-time communication of patient care events between providers and payers. EHR systems are central to generating and receiving these notifications. Payer systems are key recipients, using the information for care management and coordination. While not the primary focus, Clinical Decision Support systems could leverage these notifications for timely alerts. Public Health Systems might utilize these notifications for population health monitoring in specific scenarios. Other systems have limited or no direct involvement.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: The Da Vinci Unsolicited Notifications IG primarily focuses on enabling real-time communication of patient care events between providers and payers. Clinical Care Teams and Payers are the core users, driving the design and specifications. Healthcare Administrators and Public Health Agencies have important, well-defined needs, while Research Organizations and Government Agencies have minimal involvement.
